We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, recent HIV diagnosis, and low CD4+ T-lymphocyte count suggest a possible underlying infection, with herpes simplex virus being the most likely cause of the esophageal ulcers seen on esophagogastroduodenoscopy. Transient lower esophageal sphincter relaxation is a physiological mechanism that may contribute to gastroesophageal reflux disease, but would not cause ulcers. Degeneration of inhibitory neurons within the myenteric plexuses can cause achalasia, but would not cause esophageal ulcers. Cytomegalovirus can also cause esophageal ulcers in patients with HIV, but herpes simplex virus is a more common cause.
